channel.title: Partition resizing error
channel.description:
i have a dual boot setup on my laptop. on one partition i have windows xp sp3 installed and on the other partition i have ubuntu 9.04
my winxp partition contains 80 GB and my ubuntu partition contains 40 GB. today, i tried to resize my windows partition to 60 GB and my ubuntu partition to 25 GB in order to create a 35 GB partition. i did all of this using paragon
so paragon told me to restart computer because win partition was in use, etc. so when i restart it boots into paragon and starts doing everything as it usually would. after a few minutes of running however, i receive an error message as follows: "Some error occurred. File system has allocation errors due to cross linked files..." then it exits paragon and restarts my computer, leaving the partitions as they were without creating new partition
help
[br][br][size=1]Posted on: October 20, 2009, 02:38:50 pm[/size][hr]thanks for the lack of help, but i have fixed this through running CHKDSK on my windows partition. turns out, a trojan i was infected with a couple of days ago created files that pointed to data-clusters that were already in use, and thus fucking my FAT up
this can be locked now

item.title: Partition resizing error
item.dc:creator: @blah_bah7 blah bah7
item.description:
@blah_bah7 wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:3, topic:309623”][quote author=blah bah7 link=topic=406076.msg3002157#msg3002157 date=1256082193]
Just a suggestion though, use gparted live.
[/quote]Just a suggestion though, read threads before responding to them; this was solved.

by the way, i tried to use gparted but it just wouldnt let me resize either of my partitions, so ya[/quote]

To be honest, I don’t care if it was answered or not, I’m gonna throw my ideas out there, if your gonna bitch about me helpin… gtfo.

Best part of gparted, its free.

Read full topic

item.title: Partition resizing error
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I re-size all of my partitions all the time with gparted, great program.
